sections.title: Emergency dentistry
sections.body:
If you’re in pain, have swelling, or you’ve damaged a tooth, the first job is to work out what’s urgent and what’s fixable — calmly.

Emergency care is usually about stabilising the situation: getting you comfortable, reducing risk, and planning the right longer-term repair.

If you’re unsure whether you need to be seen quickly, contact us and we’ll guide you.
bullets: Assess what’s happening and how urgent it is
Settle pain and stabilise the problem safely
Explain the next step and the longer-term plan

sections.label: Introduction
sections.title: How we handle dental emergencies
sections.body:
A dental emergency is any situation where pain, swelling, trauma, or infection needs prompt assessment.

Not all urgent dental problems look the same, and not all require the same response. Our role is to assess the situation, relieve pain where possible, and decide what treatment is needed to stabilise the problem safely.

If you are unsure whether your situation counts as an emergency, contacting the practice for advice is appropriate.

sections.title: Common reasons people contact us urgently
items: Dental emergencies may include severe toothache, facial swelling, dental trauma, bleeding that does not settle, or signs of infection.
Some problems feel urgent but may not require immediate treatment, while others benefit from early assessment even if pain is mild. Speaking to a dentist allows us to prioritise care appropriately.

sections.title: What to do right now
items: If you are experiencing dental pain or swelling, contact the practice as soon as you can during opening hours so we can advise on the next steps.
We will ask about your symptoms and may offer advice, an urgent appointment, or referral depending on the situation. Outside normal hours, guidance will be provided on how to access appropriate care.
If swelling affects breathing, swallowing, or causes rapidly worsening symptoms, urgent medical attention may be required.

sections.label: Common emergency situations
sections.title: What you can expect at an emergency visit
sections.body:
Emergency dental care focuses on assessment, pain control, and stabilisation.

The aim is to address the immediate problem safely, then discuss longer-term treatment once the urgent issue has settled. In some cases, definitive treatment is not appropriate during an emergency visit.

We will explain findings clearly and outline any recommended follow-up care.

sections.title: After an emergency visit
sections.body:
Following emergency care, further treatment may be recommended to address the underlying cause.

We’ll explain any findings clearly and discuss whether monitoring, further investigation, or planned treatment is appropriate.

You’ll have time to consider options once the immediate situation has settled.

sections.title: When urgent care may not be necessary

faqs.question: When urgent care may not be necessary
faqs.answer:
Some issues can wait a short time — for example, a small chip with no pain, a lost filling that isn’t sensitive, or mild sensitivity that settles quickly.

If you’re unsure, it’s still worth contacting us. We can help you work out whether it sounds urgent, and what to do while you’re waiting.
